:orange_circle: [BDSA-2019-4362](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2019-4362)([CVE-2019-10747](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-10747)) - set-value Vulnerable to Prototype Pollution via 'set' Function


## Solution
Fixed in version [**4.0.1**](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/set-value/releases/tag/4.0.1) by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/set-value/commit/383b72d47c74a55ae8b6e231da548f9280a4296a) commit.

Fixed in [**2.0.1**](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/set-value/releases/tag/2.0.1) by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/set-value/commit/cb12f14955dde6e61829d70d1851bfea6a3c31ad) commit.

## Description
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-2631](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-2631)([CVE-2021-37701](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-37701)) - tar Vulnerable to Arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite/Code Execution via Directory Cache Poisoning


## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**4.4.16**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.16) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/3f2e2da3866c4e5f26ca0c0d6721cb371c5a3933) commit. 
* [**5.0.8**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.8) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/ab3e9036dc4504413fb6f154ea6943af5c187e26)commit. 
* [**6.1.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/53602669f58ddbeb3294d7196b3320aaaed22728) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).

## Workaround
Users can workaround this vulnerability by creating a custom filter method (`x` in this example) which prevents all symbolic links from being extracted:

```
const tar = require('tar')

tar.x({
  file: 'archive.tgz',
  filter: (file, entry) => {
    if (entry.type === 'SymbolicLink') {
      return false
    } else {
      return true
    }
  }
})
```

## Description
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-2632](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-2632)([CVE-2021-37712](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-37712)) - tar Vulnerable to Arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite/Code Execution via Directory Cache Poisoning


## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**4.4.18**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.18) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/3f2e2da3866c4e5f26ca0c0d6721cb371c5a3933) commit and [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/bb93ba243746f705092905da1955ac3b0509ba1e). 
* [**5.0.10**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.10) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/ab3e9036dc4504413fb6f154ea6943af5c187e26) commit and [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/1739408d3122af897caefd09662bce2ea477533b) commit. 
* [**6.1.9**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.9) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/b6162c7fafe797f856564ef37f4b82747f051455) commit and [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/53602669f58ddbeb3294d7196b3320aaaed22728) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).

## Workaround
Users can workaround this vulnerability by creating a custom filter method (`x` in this example) which prevents all symbolic links from being extracted:

```
const tar = require('tar')

tar.x({
  file: 'archive.tgz',
  filter: (file, entry) => {
    if (entry.type === 'SymbolicLink') {
      return false
    } else {
      return true
    }
  }
})
```

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: tar 4.4.8 from nodemon 1.19.1 (CVE-2021-32803 BDSA-2021-2334)

fullDescription.text:
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Description
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2021-2334](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2021-2334)([CVE-2021-32803](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-32803)) - node-tar Vulnerable to Arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite via Insufficient Symlink Protection due to Directory Cache Poisoning


## Solution
Fixed in:
* [**3.2.3**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v3.2.3) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/85d3a942b4064e4ff171f91696fced7975167349) commit,
* [**4.4.15**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.15) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/46fe35083e2676e31c4e0a81639dce6da7aaa356) commit, 
* [**5.0.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/5987d9a41f6bfbf1ddab1098e1fdcf1a5618f571) commit, 
* [**6.1.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/9dbdeb6df8e9dbd96fa9e84341b9d74734be6c20) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases).

## Workaround
It is suggested on [npmjs.com](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1771#workarounds) that it is possible to mitigate the vulnerability by creating a custom `onentry` method which sanitizes the `entry.path` or a `filter` method which removes entries with absolute paths.

## Description
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

shortDescription.text: Transitive Dependency: minimist 1.2.0 from cypress 3.3.1 (CVE-2021-44906 BDSA-2022-0771)

fullDescription.text:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

## Description
Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

## Workaround
A patch has been proposed [here](https://github.com/request/request/pull/3444/commits/d42332182512e56ba68446f49c3e3711e04301a2) that has not been merged with the upstream repository yet.

## Description
Mixin-deep is vulnerable to prototype pollution attack. This could allow an attacker to manipulate a function to add or modify properties of `Object.prototype` via a constructor payload. Successfully exploiting results in a denial-of-service (DoS) and code execution may be possible.

## Vulnerabilities(BDSA,CVE)
:orange_circle: [BDSA-2019-2162](https://openhub.net/vulnerabilities/bdsa/BDSA-2019-2162)([CVE-2019-10746](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-10746)) - Mixin-deep Vulnerable to Denial-of-Service (DoS) Due to Prototype Pollution Attack via 'Object.prototype'


## Solution
Fixed in:

* **[1.3.2](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/releases/tag/1.3.2)** by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/commit/90ee1fab375fccfd9b926df718243339b4976d50) commit.
* **[2.0.1](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/releases/tag/2.0.1)** by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/commit/8f464c8ce9761a8c9c2b3457eaeee9d404fa7af9) commit.

## Workaround
1. Freeze the prototype use Object.freeze (Object.prototype).
2. Require schema validation of JSON input.
3. Avoid using unsafe recursive merge functions.
4. Consider using objects without prototypes (for example, Object.create(null)), breaking the prototype chain and preventing pollution.
5. As a best practice use Map instead of Object.

## Solution
Fixed in [**9.0.1**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hawk/v/9.0.1) by [this](https://github.com/mozilla/hawk/commit/d10d72ca82db967f6c5fcf866ff78e3ca25ce1ab) commit.

The vendor has issued the following workaround:

"`Hawk.authenticate()` accepts the options argument. If that contains host and port, those would be used instead of a call to `utils.parseHost()`".

If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.

Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).

lodash.set is vulnerable to prototype pollution. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.
Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or cause remote code execution or a denial-of-service (*DoS*).
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.

Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to functionality that allows users to influence protoypes. An attacker could cause a vulnerable application to crash by providing malicious input that modifies JavaScript prototypes within the application. It may also be possible for an attacker to modify data that exists within the application.
Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or create a denial-of-service (DoS).

The `package.json` file generated by node package manager for the lodash library contains out-dated information. The `contributors` section of the package.json file contains an URL that has been flagged for serving malware.

Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

node-cross-spawn contains a regular expression catastrophic backtracking issue in its `escapeArgument` function. A remote attacker able to supply specially crafted input to this function could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.

node-cross-spawn contains a regular expression catastrophic backtracking issue in its `escapeArgument` function. A remote attacker able to supply specially crafted input to this function could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

brace-expansion is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issue due to the presence of an inefficient regular expression in the `index.js` file.

An attacker could submit a crafted input to an affected application in order to trigger excessive resource consumption that could result in degraded performance.

Mime is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to a poorly implemented regular expression.  A remote attacker could impact the performance of a vulnerable application, or perhaps cause it to crash, by causing it to process a maliciously crafted path.

Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

marked contains a stored cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability. This allows an attacker to execute malicious JavaScript code in a victim's instance of marked, which could be used to steal session tokens, cookies, or other sensitive information.
Marked is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (*XSS*) due to improper validation of user-supplied input. This vulnerability can be used to execute JavaScript-based attacks.

Marked is vulnerable to regular expression denial of service (ReDoS) due to a flaw present within a regular expression in the `src/rules.js` file. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted input in order to consume resources, thus resulting in a denial-of-service (DoS) condition occurring.

Marked is vulnerable to regular expression denial of service (ReDoS) due to a flaw present within a regular expression in the `src/rules.js` file. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted input in order to consume resources, thus resulting in a denial-of-service (DoS) condition occurring.

Marked is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to improper regex use when parsing HTML tags and markdown links. This could be exploited by an attacker by supplying an application with crafted markdown.

The Node.js marked module contains a flaw when handling regular expressions. The component uses a vulnerable regular expression when parsing markdown content which is vulnerable to exponential blowup. This could be exploited by an attacker to cause a slowdown and denial-of-service (*DoS*) condition. Requests will be delayed, but eventually processed.
is_my_json_valid is vulnerable to arbitrary code execution via the improper input validation in the `formatName` function.
is_my_json_valid is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) via the `style` format.

form-data generates random values using an pseudo random number generator (PRNG). If a remote attacker is able to view sequential values that are generated, they could predict future values which may allow them to modify HTTP request parameters.

Spring Framework contains an inefficient regular expression for its handling of Etags. If an application parses ETags from "If-Match" or "If-None-Match" request headers, a remote attacker could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

Spring Framework fails to properly limit resource consumption for Spring Expression Language (SpEL) expressions. A remote attacker able to supply a specially crafted expression could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

Spring Framework contains a path traversal flaw when used to serve static resources through the functional web frameworks `WebMvc.fn` or `WebFlux.fn`. A remote attacker could leverage this to read arbitrary files that the application has system read rights to.

**Note**: The application is only vulnerable when it uses `RouterFunctions` to serve static resources and resource handling is explicitly configured with a `FileSystemResource` location.

Spring Framework is vulnerable to a path traversal issue due to a lack of sufficient sanitization of path sequences processed by the `WebMvc.fn` or `WebFlux.fn` functional web frameworks.

A remote attacker could submit crafted HTTP requests to an application that serves static resources through the affected frameworks in order to read any file on the system that is accessible to the process in which the Spring application is running.

An application is vulnerable when both of the following are true:
* the web application uses `RouterFunctions` to serve static resources, and
* resource handling is explicitly configured with a `FileSystemResource` location

The vendor has noted in the official [advisory](https://spring.io/security/cve-2024-38819) that malicious requests are blocked and rejected when the Spring Security HTTP Firewall is in use.

**Note**: This issue exists due to an insufficient fix for the previously reported path traversal issue **CVE-2024-38816** (**BDSA-2024-6528**). Unlike **CVE-2024-38816**, applications deployed on Tomcat or Jetty are vulnerable.

Spring framework contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability that may be exploited via Spring MVC controller methods with `@RequestBody byte[]` method parameter.

**Note**: this vulnerability has only been addressed in a commercial version of Spring Framework, version **5.3.42**.

Spring Framework is vulnerable to path traversal when it has been deployed on a non-compliant servlet container. A remote attacker could exploit this vulnerability in order to view sensitive information.

An application can be vulnerable when all the following are true:
* the application is deployed as a WAR or with an embedded Servlet container,
* the Servlet container does not reject suspicious sequences,
* the application serves static resources with Spring resource handling.

**Note**: The vendor has stated that applications deployed on Apache Tomcat or Eclipse Jetty are not vulnerable, as long as default security features are not disabled in the configuration.

The Spring Framework might not correctly detect annotations on methods if those methods are part of a class hierarchy that uses generic types without specific type limits. If these annotations are used for authorization purposes, a remote attacker could exploit this vulnerability in order to reveal information that they should not have access to.

**Note:** The vendor has stated that only instances of spring that use the `@EnableMethodSecurity` setting or use security annotations on methods in generic superclasses or generic interfaces are vulnerable.

Spring Framework contains locale-dependent exceptions in the `disallowedFields` patterns in the `DataBinder` component. This could allow an attacker to bypass field protections and potentially manipulate protected fields.

**Note:** after this CVE was fixed it was discovered that there are still cases where it is possible to bypass the disallowedFields checks, resulting in **CVE-2025-22233** and a second fix.

Spring Framework is vulnerable to a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) issue due to the presence of a security bypass flaw in the STOMP protocol functionality. Applications that use STOMP over WebSocket are affected by this issue.

An attacker could trick a victim user into viewing crafted web content that sends requests to an affected application and abuses improper state management to bypass security measures and send unauthorized messages on the victim user's behalf.

It was discovered that the fix for Spring Framework **CVE-2024-38820** (field protection bypass via locale-dependent exceptions in the `disallowedFields` patterns) is incomplete. There are still cases where it is possible to bypass the `disallowedFields` checks and potentially manipulate protected fields.

A privilege escalation vulnerability in the Scala compilation daemon allows a local attacker to write arbitrary class files and execute code as the user that started the daemon. The vulnerability is caused by using weak permissions for private files in `/tmp/scaladev/${USER:shared}/scalac-compile-server-port`.

ansi-regex is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issue due to how certain crafted ANSI escaped codes are mishandled.

An attacker could submit a crafted string that, when matched, could cause excessive consumption of system resources that will impact stability and potentially cause a crash.

The braces NPM package is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) via memory exhaustion due to lack of any restriction on the number of input characters it processes. An application that uses the library and accepts remote user input may be susceptible to the attack via a payload containing a large number of "imbalanced braces", `{` characters.

qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.
qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (*DoS*) due to improper validation of user-supplied input. This could allow an attacker to render services unavailable or potentially craft other attacks.

Apache Commons contains a flaw that is due to the Base32 codec decoding  invalid strings instead of rejecting them. This may allow a remote attacker to tunnel  additional information via a base 32 string that seems valid.

The hoek module for Node is vulnerable to prototype pollution. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to modify the `Object` prototype which causes additional properties or changes to exist on all objects.

Node.js module Hoek is vulnerable to prototype pollution attack due to insufficient validation of user input. Local attackers could leverage this vulnerability to cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.

The handlebars package for Node.js is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to improper restrictions on object access in templates which can lead to prototype pollution. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying maliciously crafted input.

The handlebars package is vulnerable to arbitrary code execution via prototype pollution. A remote attacker can run malicious code by modifying properties of the Object prototype. Unsuccessful attacks may result in an application crash.

It was discovered the Handlebars package is vulnerable to arbitrary code execution via prototype pollution. A remote attacker could exploit this to run malicious code by modifying properties of the Object prototype.

The handlebars package is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) and remote code execution (RCE) attacks due to improper validation of user-supplied input. In a cross-site scripting scenario, an attacker could exploit this to pass malicious arbitrary JavaScript into template, which will execute when a victim visits the crafted page. If handlebars is used to run on the server side, remote code execution is possible.

handlebars.js, an extension to the Mustache templating language, is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution when compiling templates that come from untrusted sources. Although successful exploitation could result in remote code execution (RCE), it also requires that a certain compilation option is used.

handlebars.js, an extension to the Mustache templating language, is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) when compiling templates that come from untrusted sources. Successful exploitation also requires certain compilation options to be used.

handlebars.js, an extension to Mustache, contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. An attacker could exploit this issue by accessing prototype properties and methods, which may result in the attacker being able to force an application crash or gain the ability to execute arbitrary code.

The stringstream package for Node.js is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.  If an application is supplying untrusted user input to the `write` function, an attacker can trigger an out-of-bounds read that may result in uninitilzed memory being exposed of the application crashing.

Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

es5-ext contains ECMAScript 5 extensions. Passing functions with very long names or complex default argument names into `function#copy` or `function#toStringTokens` may cause the script to stall. The vulnerability is patched in v0.10.63.

Spring framework contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability that may be exploited via Spring MVC controller methods with `@RequestBody byte[]` method parameter.

**Note**: this vulnerability has only been addressed in a commercial version of Spring Framework, version **5.3.42**.

**Note:** The vendor has stated that only instances of spring that use the `@EnableMethodSecurity` setting or use security annotations on methods in generic superclasses or generic interfaces are vulnerable.

Spring Framework contains locale-dependent exceptions in the `disallowedFields` patterns in the `DataBinder` component. This could allow an attacker to bypass field protections and potentially manipulate protected fields.

**Note:** after this CVE was fixed it was discovered that there are still cases where it is possible to bypass the disallowedFields checks, resulting in **CVE-2025-22233** and a second fix.

ShellJS is vulnerable to privilege escalation and denial-of-service (DoS) issues due to how file permissions used by the internal implementation of `shell.exec()` are mishandled.

If ShellJS scripts running locally are using the ShellJS `exec()` function, an attacker with low-level privileges on the system could abuse the flaw in order to leak sensitive information, such as passwords, in order to perform local privilege escalation or shutdown privileged ShellJS processes.

A vendor comment [here](https://github.com/shelljs/shelljs/issues/1058#issuecomment-1008657537) indicates that this issue only impacts the `synchronous` version of `shell.exec()`. All other ShellJS methods (including the `async` usage of `shell.exec()`) should not be impacted.

ShellJS is vulnerable to information disclosure due to the unsafe handling of the `stdout` and `stderr` streams of the `shell.exec()` function. A local attacker could potentially obtain sensitive data that has been produced by processes by examining the `stdout` file that is produced by ShellJS. This vulnerability can also be leveraged to crash privileged ShellJS processes.

It should be noted that only the synchronous version of `shell.exec()` function is affected by this issue.

tough-cookie is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to improper handling of cookies when using `CookieJar` in `rejectPublicSuffixes=false` mode.  An attacker can use this vulnerability to override the global object prototype in order to cause unspecified impacts.
By supplying a large HTTP request cookie header to an application using the Tough-Cookie Node.js an attacker could cause the application to consume an excessive amount of CPU.
tough-cookie is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to improper validation of cookie headers. This could allow an attacker to potentially render services unavailable.
Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or cause remote code execution or a denial-of-service (*DoS*).

Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.

lodash is vulnerable to a prototype pollution flaw. A remote attacker may be able to supply specially crafted input to cause serious confidentiality, integrity and availability impacts to the application. In the past, such vulnerabilities have lead to remote code execution (RCE) in the end application.

lodash.set is vulnerable to prototype pollution. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).
Lodash is vulnerable to command injection via the `template` function. An attacker can take advantage of this vulnerability in order to run arbitrary commands.

Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to functionality that allows users to influence protoypes. An attacker could cause a vulnerable application to crash by providing malicious input that modifies JavaScript prototypes within the application. It may also be possible for an attacker to modify data that exists within the application.
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.

The `package.json` file generated by node package manager for the lodash library contains out-dated information. The `contributors` section of the package.json file contains an URL that has been flagged for serving malware.
The NPM CLI is vulnerable to arbitrary file write via a symlink. An attacker must trick their target into installing a package with a crafted `bin` entry.
The NPM CLI is vulnerable to file overwriting. An attacker must trick their target into installing a package with a crafted `bin` entry.
The NPM CLI is vulnerable to arbitrary file write via the `bin` field in `package.json`. An attacker must trick their target into installing a package with a crafted `bin` entry.
npn CLI contains an information disclosure vulnerability. This allows an attacker to gain access to other users passwords.
Prototype pollution vulnerability in 'getobject' version 0.1.0 allows an attacker to cause a denial of service and may lead to remote code execution.
chownr contains a time-of-check time-of-use (TOCTOU) race condition vulnerability. A local attacker that successfully exploits this could descend into unintended directories via symlink attacks.
trim-newlines contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.

The Underscore Javascript library contains an arbitrary code execution vulnerability.  This allows an attacker to create malicious content that, if processed by Underscore may lead to the execution of code on a system.

bl is vulnerable to information exposure and denial-of-service (DoS) due to the improper handling of buffer operations. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a system with maliciously crafted input.

GruntJS contains a TOCTOU (Time of Check to Time of Use) race condition. An attacker with low-level privileges could exploit this issue by creating a symlink at a specific time. This may lead to the ability for an attacker to arbitrarily write files and potentially allow for local privilege escalation.

Grunt is vulnerable to an remote code execution (RCE) issue due to how the `load()` function is used by default to load YAML files.

An attacker could provide a crafted YAML file that, when loaded, could generate executable code and allow the attacker to run arbitrary code on the system.
grunt is vulnerable to a symlink following flaw that allows path traversal. If the application is run with high privileges this could allow a local attacker to read and write protected system files.

qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.
Lodash is vulnerable to command injection via the `template` function. An attacker can take advantage of this vulnerability in order to run arbitrary commands.
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.

The MongoDB driver for Node.js is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper exception handling. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying an application with maliciously crafted data.

The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via insufficient absolute path sanitization.
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite via insufficient relative path sanitization. 

**Note:** This only affects users on Windows systems.
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

node-tar is vulnerable to the overwriting of files due to a lack of safety checks in its default extraction functionality. An attacker could overwrite files on the host filesystem by supplying a crafted tar file to an application that uses node-tar's unpack functionality.

node-tar is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) condition due to missing limits on sub-folder creation during the folder creation process. An attacker could exploit this by generating a large number of sub-folder in order to consume memory on the system running node-tar and or to crash the Node.js client.

Node Semver is vulnerable due to improper handling of whitespaces. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by providing a crafted input in order to cause a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).

A memory leak issue has been detected in Inflight. A local attacker could exploit this in order to cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via a crash of the node process or an application crash. 

**Note:** The Inflight project has not been updated for some time and may no longer be maintained.

protobuf-java is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper handling of nested SGROUP tags when parsing with `DiscardUnknownFieldsParser`, the Java Protobuf Lite parser, or against Protobuf map fields. This could allow an attacker to trigger unbounded recursions which can lead to a stack overflow.

**Note**: the vendor states that this issue affects all versions of both the Java full and lite Protobuf runtimes, as well as Protobuf for Kotlin and JRuby, which themselves use the Java Protobuf runtime.

Serve-static, a component of Express.js, is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) due to the unsafe handling of user input in the `redirect` function. This could allow an attacker to execute untrusted code, potentially leading to unauthorized access or data manipulation.

path-parse contains a vulnerability to regular expression denial of service (ReDoS). An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted input to consume the application's resources, thus resulting in a denial-of-service condition occurring.

The randomatic module for Node.js generates random values using a cryptographically weak psuedo-random number generator. This might produce predictable values rather than random ones making it possible for an attacker to exploit this vulnerability via brute forcing.

dot-prop is vulnerable to a prototype pollution flaw. A remote attacker able to supply specially crafted input to a dot-prop method could cause a denial-of-service (DoS) of the application, or affect its integrity, depending on the application code. Although unlikely, if the application uses polluted objects in conjunction with code execution primitives (such as eval), remote code execution could be possible.

JSON Pointer is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack due to a type confusion error. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

brace-expansion is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issue due to the presence of an inefficient regular expression in the `index.js` file.

An attacker could submit a crafted input to an affected application in order to trigger excessive resource consumption that could result in degraded performance.

brace-expansion is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to a flaw in the process of expansion of expressions. An attacker could leverage this flaw by supplying a crafted regular expression to cause resource overconsumption and make the target application hang.

Babel Traverse is vulnerable to an arbitrary code execution issue due to how the `_evaluate()` function allows for the evaluation of inherited methods. This affects plugins that rely on the `path.evaluate()` or `path.evaluateTruthy()` internal Babel methods.

In cases where Babel is used to compile untrusted code, an attacker could potentially submit specially crafted code that, during compilation, could be evaluated and executed during the compilation process.

send is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) via template injection. Developers can unknowingly expose themselves to increased risk of XSS because passing untrusted user input to the steam redirect function may execute the untrusted code, even if it has supposedly been sanitized. A remote attacker could insert JavaScript code in order to steal a victim's session tokens, cookies, or other sensitive information.
Directory traversal vulnerability in swig-templates thru 2.0.4 and swig thru 1.4.2, allows attackers to read arbitrary files via the include or extends tags.

node-cross-spawn contains a regular expression catastrophic backtracking issue in its `escapeArgument` function. A remote attacker able to supply specially crafted input to this function could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

The websocket-extensions npm package is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to improper regular expression parsing with WebSocket handshakes. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a system with maliciously crafted requests.

Apache Tika is vulnerable to an XML external entities (XXE) injection vulnerability due to how the `PDFParser` functionality, `(tike-parser-pdf-module`), automatically resolves external entities present in XML Forms Architecture (XFA) resources.

An attacker could submit a crafted PDF file that includes malicious XFA content to an affected application in order to trigger entity expansion, which could potentially be abused in order to read sensitive data or trigger malicious requests to internal resources or third-party servers.

**Note**: The vendor has highlighted that the `tika-parser-pdf-module` is used as a dependency in multiple Tika packages including `tika-parsers-standard-modules`, `tika-parsers-standard-package`, `tika-app`, `tika-grpc` and `tika-server-standard`.

**Note:** This issue was assigned a new CVE, **CVE-2025-66516** (**BDSA-2025-43183**), as the original CVE did not list the full range of effected products and did not state that users who updated `tika-parser-pdf-module` to the fixed version but did not update `tika-core` to 3.2.2 would still be vulnerable.

Apache Tika is vulnerable to an XML external entities (XXE) injection vulnerability due to how the `PDFParser` functionality, `(tike-parser-pdf-module`), automatically resolves external entities present in XML Forms Architecture (XFA) resources.

An attacker could submit a crafted PDF file that includes malicious XFA content to an affected application in order to trigger entity expansion, which could potentially be abused in order to read sensitive data or trigger malicious requests to internal resources or third-party servers.

**Note**: The vendor has highlighted that the `tika-parser-pdf-module` is used as a dependency in multiple Tika packages including `tika-parsers-standard-modules`, `tika-parsers-standard-package`, `tika-app`, `tika-grpc` and `tika-server-standard`

**Note:** This vulnerability is the same vulnerability described by **CVE-2025-54988** (**BDSA-2025-9587**), however this issue was assigned a new CVE as the original CVE did not list the full range of effected products and did not state that users who updated `tika-parser-pdf-module` to the fixed version but did not update `tika-core` to 3.2.2 would still be vulnerable.

micromatch is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to the use of an insecure regular expression. If this vulnerability is successfully exploited, it could cause the application to slow down or crash.

Bson contains a deserialization of untrusted data vulnerability due to improper handling of user input. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability through specially crafted input which could lead to the application treating the input in a way it was not intended, such as data disclosure.
js-bson contains an information disclosure vulnerability. This allows an attacker that is able to supply crafted data to applications using js-bson to potentially disclose information.

Node Semver is vulnerable due to improper handling of whitespaces. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by providing a crafted input in order to cause a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).
Hawk, a HTTP authentication scheme, is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (*ReDoS*) due to its implementation of pattern matching.
Node.js Hawk contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources and cause a crash.

form-data generates random values using an pseudo random number generator (PRNG). If a remote attacker is able to view sequential values that are generated, they could predict future values which may allow them to modify HTTP request parameters.

Express.js web framework is vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) due to the improper handling of user input in the `response.redirect()` function. This could allow an attacker to execute JavaScript code on the users browser.

**Note** The attacker must be in control of the input to `response.redirect()` and the user must click before the redirect occurs.

Express.js contains an open redirect vulnerability due to insufficient validation of user supplied URLs. An attacker could exploit this by providing a crafted URL when performing a redirect bypassing the redirect allow list leading to an open redirect.

An open redirect vulnerability has been discovered in Got due to the insufficient validation of URLs. An attacker could exploit this by tricking a user into clicking a malicious link that may be controlled by an attacker.
Unicode-org's ICU contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This allows an attacker to cause applications using certain functionality from ICU to crash due to memory corruption.

Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

The kind-of module contains a validation bypass vulnerability.  This allows attacker to potentially bypass validation checks being performed on user-supplied input by applications using the kind-of module.

JSON Pointer is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack due to a type confusion error. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

The braces NPM package is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) via memory exhaustion due to lack of any restriction on the number of input characters it processes. An application that uses the library and accepts remote user input may be susceptible to the attack via a payload containing a large number of "imbalanced braces", `{` characters.

The braces package for Node.js contains a bad regular expression that causes catastrophic back tracking. If an application is supplying untrusted input to this module, it is possible for an attacker to input a string that will cause the application to hang or possibly crash due to resource exhaustion. This is better known as a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).

form-data generates random values using an pseudo random number generator (PRNG). If a remote attacker is able to view sequential values that are generated, they could predict future values which may allow them to modify HTTP request parameters.

The hoek module for Node is vulnerable to prototype pollution. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to modify the `Object` prototype which causes additional properties or changes to exist on all objects.

Node.js module Hoek is vulnerable to prototype pollution attack due to insufficient validation of user input. Local attackers could leverage this vulnerability to cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.

nconf is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient input validation within the memory engine. This could allow an attacker to maliciously modify object prototypes, which depending on how objects are used by an application, could cause impacts such as denial-of-service (DoS), cross-site scripting (XSS) or remote code execution (RCE).

Minimatch package contains a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) vulnerability because of improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this flaw by calling the `braceExpand()` function with specific arguments.

decode-uri-component contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. Successful exploitation of this issue enables an unauthenticated attacker to cause an application crash within the decoding process, by supplying a crafted input file.

Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

Request contains a memory disclosure vulnerability due to issues in file `liv/multipart.js` with `multipart` attachments. A remote attacker is able to gain a specified number of non-zero memory due to it being disclosed within the body of the request.

tough-cookie is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to improper handling of cookies when using `CookieJar` in `rejectPublicSuffixes=false` mode.  An attacker can use this vulnerability to override the global object prototype in order to cause unspecified impacts.
By supplying a large HTTP request cookie header to an application using the Tough-Cookie Node.js an attacker could cause the application to consume an excessive amount of CPU.

Spring Framework fails to properly limit resource consumption for Spring Expression Language (SpEL) expressions. A remote attacker able to supply a specially crafted expression could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

Spring Framework contains a path traversal flaw when used to serve static resources through the functional web frameworks `WebMvc.fn` or `WebFlux.fn`. A remote attacker could leverage this to read arbitrary files that the application has system read rights to.

**Note**: The application is only vulnerable when it uses `RouterFunctions` to serve static resources and resource handling is explicitly configured with a `FileSystemResource` location.

Spring Framework contains an inefficient regular expression for its handling of Etags. If an application parses ETags from "If-Match" or "If-None-Match" request headers, a remote attacker could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

Spring framework contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability that may be exploited via Spring MVC controller methods with `@RequestBody byte[]` method parameter.

**Note**: this vulnerability has only been addressed in a commercial version of Spring Framework, version **5.3.42**.

Spring Framework is vulnerable to a path traversal issue due to a lack of sufficient sanitization of path sequences processed by the `WebMvc.fn` or `WebFlux.fn` functional web frameworks.

A remote attacker could submit crafted HTTP requests to an application that serves static resources through the affected frameworks in order to read any file on the system that is accessible to the process in which the Spring application is running.

An application is vulnerable when both of the following are true:
* the web application uses `RouterFunctions` to serve static resources, and
* resource handling is explicitly configured with a `FileSystemResource` location

The vendor has noted in the official [advisory](https://spring.io/security/cve-2024-38819) that malicious requests are blocked and rejected when the Spring Security HTTP Firewall is in use.

**Note**: This issue exists due to an insufficient fix for the previously reported path traversal issue **CVE-2024-38816** (**BDSA-2024-6528**). Unlike **CVE-2024-38816**, applications deployed on Tomcat or Jetty are vulnerable.

Spring Framework is vulnerable to path traversal when it has been deployed on a non-compliant servlet container. A remote attacker could exploit this vulnerability in order to view sensitive information.

An application can be vulnerable when all the following are true:
* the application is deployed as a WAR or with an embedded Servlet container,
* the Servlet container does not reject suspicious sequences,
* the application serves static resources with Spring resource handling.

**Note**: The vendor has stated that applications deployed on Apache Tomcat or Eclipse Jetty are not vulnerable, as long as default security features are not disabled in the configuration.

The Spring Framework might not correctly detect annotations on methods if those methods are part of a class hierarchy that uses generic types without specific type limits. If these annotations are used for authorization purposes, a remote attacker could exploit this vulnerability in order to reveal information that they should not have access to.

**Note:** The vendor has stated that only instances of spring that use the `@EnableMethodSecurity` setting or use security annotations on methods in generic superclasses or generic interfaces are vulnerable.

It was discovered that the fix for Spring Framework **CVE-2024-38820** (field protection bypass via locale-dependent exceptions in the `disallowedFields` patterns) is incomplete. There are still cases where it is possible to bypass the `disallowedFields` checks and potentially manipulate protected fields.

Spring Framework is vulnerable to a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) issue due to the presence of a security bypass flaw in the STOMP protocol functionality. Applications that use STOMP over WebSocket are affected by this issue.

An attacker could trick a victim user into viewing crafted web content that sends requests to an affected application and abuses improper state management to bypass security measures and send unauthorized messages on the victim user's behalf.

Spring Framework contains locale-dependent exceptions in the `disallowedFields` patterns in the `DataBinder` component. This could allow an attacker to bypass field protections and potentially manipulate protected fields.

**Note:** after this CVE was fixed it was discovered that there are still cases where it is possible to bypass the disallowedFields checks, resulting in **CVE-2025-22233** and a second fix.
nodejs-ajv is vulnerable to a prototype pollution flaw. A remote attacker could leverage this to execute arbitrary code.

form-data generates random values using an pseudo random number generator (PRNG). If a remote attacker is able to view sequential values that are generated, they could predict future values which may allow them to modify HTTP request parameters.

The ini package is vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks.  A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition. The impact of this vulnerability is reliant on the ini package parsing a untrusted input.
The module minimatch is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (*ReDoS*) via incorrect regular expression validation in the function `minimatch(path, pattern)`.

Minimatch package contains a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) vulnerability because of improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this flaw by calling the `braceExpand()` function with specific arguments.

lodash is vulnerable to a prototype pollution flaw. A remote attacker may be able to supply specially crafted input to cause serious confidentiality, integrity and availability impacts to the application. In the past, such vulnerabilities have lead to remote code execution (RCE) in the end application.

Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.
Lodash is vulnerable to command injection via the `template` function. An attacker can take advantage of this vulnerability in order to run arbitrary commands.
Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or cause remote code execution or a denial-of-service (*DoS*).

Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.

lodash.set is vulnerable to prototype pollution. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).

Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to functionality that allows users to influence protoypes. An attacker could cause a vulnerable application to crash by providing malicious input that modifies JavaScript prototypes within the application. It may also be possible for an attacker to modify data that exists within the application.
Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or create a denial-of-service (DoS).
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.

The `package.json` file generated by node package manager for the lodash library contains out-dated information. The `contributors` section of the package.json file contains an URL that has been flagged for serving malware.

Node Semver is vulnerable due to improper handling of whitespaces. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by providing a crafted input in order to cause a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).

Apache Commons Lang is affected by an uncontrolled recursion vulnerability in the `ClassUtils.getClass` method. A remote attacker could exploit this flaw by providing excessively long or deeply nested input strings, leading to a StackOverflowError and resulting in a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.

set-value is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient input validation.  An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to modify the Object prototype properties which causes additional properties or changes to the objects which could result in denial-of-service (DoS) or alter the integrity of the application. If the application uses polluted objects in conjunction with code execution primitives (such as eval), it may be possible for an attacker to execute malicious code.

It was later determined that this issue could be bypassed via a type confusion vulnerability as noted in **CVE-2021-23440** (**BDSA-2021-2911**).

set-value is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack due to a type confusion error which can lead to a bypass of **CVE-2019-10747** (**BDSA-2019-4362**). A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

body-parser is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) when URL encoding is enabled. An attacker could flood a server with an overwhelming number of request using a crafted payload resulting in DoS conditions.

qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.
qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (*DoS*) due to improper validation of user-supplied input. This could allow an attacker to render services unavailable or potentially craft other attacks.

Node.js module `qs` is vulnerable to a denial-of-service.  An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by suppling`qs` with a crafted string that deserializes into very large sparse arrays, resulting in the process running out of memory and eventually crashing.
qs Module is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) triggered by excessive recursion in parsing a deeply nested JSON string. An attacker can submit a specially crafted string to crash the module.

tmp contains a symbolic link following vulnerability as it is possible for the `_resolvePath ` function to resolve the `dir ` parameter to a folder outside of `tmpDir`. A local attacker could exploit this vulnerability in order to create a temporary file or directory.

fstream is vulnerable to an arbitrary file overwrite issue. Attackers could exploit this via hardlink within the `fstream.DirWriter` function, allowing for the overwriting of files on the system enabling the attacker to launch other attacks by editing, or replacing files.
glob-parent contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.

The ini package is vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks.  A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition. The impact of this vulnerability is reliant on the ini package parsing a untrusted input.
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via insufficient absolute path sanitization.

The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite via insufficient relative path sanitization. 

**Note:** This only affects users on Windows systems.
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.

node-tar is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) condition due to missing limits on sub-folder creation during the folder creation process. An attacker could exploit this by generating a large number of sub-folder in order to consume memory on the system running node-tar and or to crash the Node.js client.

Request contains a memory disclosure vulnerability due to issues in file `liv/multipart.js` with `multipart` attachments. A remote attacker is able to gain a specified number of non-zero memory due to it being disclosed within the body of the request.

Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

inflect is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to improperly defined regular expressions for classifications and underscoring. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying an application with maliciously crafted input.

cookie contains an input validation vulnerability. This could allow an attacker to inject values into the cookie `name` field which should not be allowed and may result in other fields of the cookie being escaped or containing unexpected values. This vulnerability also exists in the `path` and the `domain` field, allowing their values to alter the values of other cookie fields.

js-yaml is vulnerable to code injection due to incorrect parsing of YAML documents. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted YAML file to a vulnerable application using js-yaml and the unsafe `load()` function to parse YAML data.

js-yaml is vulnerable to a prototype pollution issue due to a lack of sufficient validation in the `storeMappingPair` functionality.

An attacker could supply a crafted YAML document that includes `__proto__` nodes designed to modify prototypes of the resulting parsed document. In applications that parse untrusted YAML data, this issue could lead to unexpected behavior or potentially the execution of arbitrary code.
js-yaml is vulnerable to an excessive resource consumption flaw. A remote attacker able to supply a specially crafted YAML file to an application using js-yaml could cause a denial-of-service (DoS).

nconf is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient input validation within the memory engine. This could allow an attacker to maliciously modify object prototypes, which depending on how objects are used by an application, could cause impacts such as denial-of-service (DoS), cross-site scripting (XSS) or remote code execution (RCE).

The Node.js `ws` module contains a flaw when handling headers containing the Object.prototype property. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending a specially crafted Sec-WebSocket-Extensions header containing the vulnerable property name as an extension or parameter. If successful, a denial-of-service (*DoS*) will occur.

undefsafe is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient restrictions being placed on object modification functionality. An attacker that is able to control the input to the `undefsafe()` function could leverage that function to modify the prototype of an object. The exact impact that the attacker can achieve will depend on how the object is used, but could potentially include cross-site scripting (XSS) and remote code execution (RCE).
json-schema is vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks. This allows an attacker that is able to supply untrusted input to applications using json-schema to potentially execute malicious code.

Async is vulnerable to a prototype pollution issue. A remote attacker may be able to abuse this issue in order to execute arbitrary code, obtain privileges, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

On-Headers is vulnerable to HTTP response header manipulation due to incorrect handling of arrays. A local attacker could exploit this vulnerability by using a crafted array in order to modify the values of HTTP response headers.

**Note:** This vulnerability only occurs when the `res.writeHead` function is used with On-Headers.

minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).

Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.

Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This could allow an attacker to use a malicious server in order to make requests on behalf of the application server and gather information about a victim's internal infrastructure. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

hosted-git-info is vulnerable to regular expression denial of service (ReDoS) via `fromUrl()`. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted input to consume resources, thus resulting in a denial-of-service (DoS) condition occurring.
is_my_json_valid is vulnerable to arbitrary code execution via the improper input validation in the `formatName` function.

is-my-json-valid is vulnerable to regular expression denial of service (ReDoS) via `formats.js`. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by supplying a maliciously crafted input to consume resources, thus resulting in a denial-of-service (DoS) condition occurring.
is_my_json_valid is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) via the `style` format.

is-my-json-valid package for Node.js is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to improper use of regular expressions for validating emails. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to cause a denial-of-service (DoS) via resource exhaustion by submitting maliciously crafted requests.

Extend for Node.js contains a prototype pollution flaw. If applications are supplying untrusted input to the extend module, an attacker could modify javaScript Objects that may create a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.

tough-cookie is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to improper handling of cookies when using `CookieJar` in `rejectPublicSuffixes=false` mode.  An attacker can use this vulnerability to override the global object prototype in order to cause unspecified impacts.

Minimatch package contains a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) vulnerability because of improper input validation. An attacker could exploit this flaw by calling the `braceExpand()` function with specific arguments.

Mixin-deep is vulnerable to prototype pollution attack. This could allow an attacker to manipulate a function to add or modify properties of `Object.prototype` via a constructor payload. Successfully exploiting results in a denial-of-service (DoS) and code execution may be possible.
Node.js Hawk contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources and cause a crash.
